subject: tyan, s7106: Initial commit for TYAN S7106
commitMessage:
tyan, s7106: Initial commit for TYAN S7106

The TYAN S7106 is a server mainboard with an Aspeed AST2500 BMC.

Signed-off-by: Oskar Senft <osk@google.com>
Change-Id: I75e4938bbc7d25bd8e949a4bae5761205aa0ff22

Uploaded patch set 2.
Description of patch set 2 set to "Changes from patchset 1: Split out uart-routing and "normalized" obmc-console config for easier overriding."

User approved, CI ok to start

Patch Set 2:

Build Started https://jenkins.openbmc.org/job/ci-openbmc/7930/

Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

I split out the uart-routing service into a separate recipe. We're using the S7106 as the basis for some Google-specific overrides and I hadn't considered how the obmc-console would be used there. Having the uart-routing and obmc-console as separate recipes is the right thing to do, I think. Sorry for the noise.

Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 4091a0d42e312c8c9ec9af6525f1074103b97639 by Patrick Williams

I just realized that this should probably not be part of obmc-console but that I should create a new recipe instead.

The reason is that in subsequent overrides of s7106, we might not want uart-routing or might want it to do something different. Having this all intermingled here makes that much harder / impossible.
I split this out into a separate recipe.
Flash size is 64MB, right?
No, it's 32 MiB on the standard TYAN S7106 board.
ACK
We need OWNERS file written also.  MAINTAINERS is effectively deprecated for this repo.
Thanks! This must have changed after I started creating the tree. Fixed.

This is in meta-tyan/common.  Why does it end up being the desired configuration for all past, present, and future Tyan machines?  Do you need a MACHINE_FEATURE or MACHINEOVERRIDE to enable this particular configuration?

That's a good point. From what I can tell (after having looked at 3 different TYAN server boards: S7106, S8026, S8036), they always follow the same pattern.

However, I agree that this needs a bit more thought. Removing it for now.

You can use a MACHINEOVERRIDE to select it.  Take a look at meta-facebook.  We have things like this in common but then use an 'inc' file to say "this machine needs this flavor of uart routing".

I highly suspect the addresses you've picked here are tied to the AST25xx class chip and they change in AST26xx (or vis-versa).

Wow.  Should we write a script for this?

Why 'Pre'?

I based this code on the solution from meta-bytedance, which in itself means that this should really live elsewhere where it can be used by different machines. But yeah, I agree, this is borderline. I'll propose a different solution in a new review.
I think you want 'oneshot' and not RemainAfterExit?

No, that's actually correct :-) We do want the "service" to hang around after "starting" it so that it will be "stopped" when obmc-console@ttyS2 stops. The goal here is to start/stop this service when obmc-console@ttyS2 starts/stops. The combination of "RemainAfterExit" and "PartOf" has the desired effect.

TBH, I think the better solution would be to teach obmc-console-service to do the aspeed-uart-routing business. I'll look into options via a separate review and some discussion on the mailing list.
Is this tyan-uart-routing or is it Aspeed?  If this is Aspeed should it go in meta-aspeed?  If it is tyan can we prepend that to the name to avoid potential collision in the future?

Thanks for the input! I think it's best to move this to a separate review. I should probably not have included it in the first version for meta-tyan.

I removed the uart-routing from this review.
There are some layers we typically add from meta-security, etc.  Do you want any of those?
Uh, where did I get this list from. Sorry for that. I updated it, following what I found for ampere and bytedance. Thank you!
There is nothing in meta-x86 and won't be in the future.
Removed, thank you!
